WHAT DID EARLY CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?
A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Charles A. Taylor
Address: 747 L.E.M. Saskatchewan Road
Birthplace: Ontario

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
   What year did you start homesteading in Western Canada? 1927
   Where did you set up housekeeping? On Homestead at Carlyle, West Butten
   How had you been living before that? Ontario
   For how many people did you prepare meals? 3 men in 1911 - 1 man in 1910
   How far was it to your nearest store? 16 miles
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a week
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
   flour, sugar, tea, B.O.P., powder, soda, beans, raisins, syrup, dried fruit etc.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Royal House Brand
   In what quantities did you buy it? By the hundred and also
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3.60 - 1914
   How much did you use Graham flour? None
   Whole wheat flour? None
   Was flour milled locally? Yes, how far away? 24 miles
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? 85¢ - 1914
   What other grain products did you use? Corn meal, corn bread
   Cornmeal? 14¢ - 35¢ - 1914 Whole wheat? Farina?
   Other?
   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Not until 1940
   How did you grind it? Grain grinder for pig feed

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Porridge, potatoes fried, syrup + bread & butter
Dinner: Potatoes, meat, pie or pudding for dessert, fresh veg. in season. Bread, butter & tea
Supper: Fried potatoes, eggs, dried fruit, Bread, butter, tea

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada? .................. Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Was back here till 1916. Always worked out.

   Give a verbal description (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

   *Pork & beans, fried potatoes, eggs, dried fruit, brown sugar*

17. **FOODS**

   *Pork & beans, fried potatoes, eggs, dried fruit, brown sugar*

18. **THAT YEAR DID YOU SERVE YOUR FIRST CHRISTMAS DINNER IN SOUTHERN TENNESSEE?**

   *Give the menu. List whose present and give their age.*

   *We had dinner Nov. 1916. Dinner was out.*
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

We used to eat more meat & potatoes, bread, dried fruits & syrups than today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems or storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

We used to buy our foods in large quantities to save trips to town. Our storage was a dugout cellar under the shack for keeping vegetables for the winter.
We used to buy our fruits — Large quantities.

But storage was a difficult problem in the past.

The shock for keeping vegetables for the winter.
